scenario:
The US economy has a history of producing the world's most valuable companies, with Apple being the current largest company with a market capitalization of $3.7 trillion. Seven other American technology companies have joined Apple in the trillion-dollar club since 2018. Oracle (ORCL) is expected to join this club within the next four years due to its growing data center infrastructure business. 

Oracle's Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) segment is its fastest-growing business, with revenue soaring by 52% year over year in the second quarter. The company's remaining performance obligations (RPOs) increased by 50% to $97 billion, indicating strong demand for its services. Oracle CEO Safra Catz predicts RPOs will grow even higher due to the volume of deals the company is signing, including a major one with Meta Platforms.

Oracle's data center infrastructure is in high demand, with Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang predicting that data center operators will spend $1 trillion over the next four years on upgrading their infrastructure to meet demand from AI developers. Oracle's OCI supercluster technology enables developers to scale up to 65,000 of Nvidia's H200 GPUs, the highest number in the industry.

Oracle's stock trades at a price-to-earnings ratio (P/E) of 40.5, but its potential earnings suggest a forward P/E of 23.5. If Oracle grows its earnings by 14.4% annually through fiscal 2028, it will be a $1.04 trillion company. Even if its P/E settles at 36.7, its valuation would still be around $950 billion.
